title: Attachment Healing
description: Explore your attachment wounds and paths to healing.

therapeutic.rationale: Core relationship needs reflect attachment foundations. Consistent-love seekers need reliability; freedom-seekers need autonomy; security-seekers need predictability; understanding-seekers need attunement. Your deepest need is often the one that was unmet in early attachment experiences.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different core needs require balance. The freedom-seeker may feel constrained by the security-seeker's needs; the security-seeker may feel anxious about the freedom-seeker's independence. Both needs are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core needs create alignment but may also create blind spots. You'll understand each other's primary need but may neglect secondary needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your deepest relationship need? Where does it come from? Is this need being met in your current relationship?

questions.text: How do past relationships affect how I show up with you?
choices: I seek more reassurance than I'd like
I'm working to trust more fully
I've healed and feel more secure

therapeutic.rationale: Past relationship impact reveals ongoing attachment work. Caution-protectors guard against repeat wounds; reassurance-seekers show activated anxiety; trust-workers are consciously healing; healed-secure shows integration. Acknowledging how the past affects the present enables conscious choice rather than reactive pattern.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different past impacts need different patience. The cautious-protector needs more trust-building; the reassurance-seeker needs more validation. Honor each other's history.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared past impacts create understanding. You know what each other carries because you carry similar wounds.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do past relationships show up in your current one? Are you reacting to the past or responding to the present?

questions.text: What helps me trust you more deeply over time?
choices: Your consistent actions matching your words

therapeutic.rationale: Trust-building factors reveal what creates safety. Action-word match builds reliability trust; vulnerability-handling builds emotional trust; hard-time commitment builds abandonment-resistance; honest communication builds transparency trust. Knowing what builds your partner's trust helps you provide it intentionally.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust-building needs mean you're watching for different evidence. The action-matcher may not notice emotional handling; the vulnerability-handler may not track consistency. Provide what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust-building values make security easier. You're both looking for the same evidence of trustworthiness.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What has built trust for you in this relationship? What would build it further? Have you communicated this?

questions.text: What attachment wound am I still healing?
choices: Fear of being controlled or smothered

therapeutic.rationale: Core attachment wounds drive relationship patterns. Abandonment-fear creates clinginess or preemptive leaving; control-fear creates distance-keeping; not-enough fear creates proving behaviors; dependency-fear creates excessive independence. Naming your wound is the first step to healing it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different attachment wounds trigger different protections. The abandonment-fearer may feel triggered by the control-fearer's distance; the control-fearer may feel triggered by the abandonment-fearer's closeness. Compassion for each other's wounds enables healing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared attachment wounds create deep understanding but may also reinforce patterns. Two abandonment-fearers may both avoid ever leaving, even when needed.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your core attachment wound? Where did it come from? How does it show up in your relationship?

questions.text: How can you best support my attachment healing?

therapeutic.rationale: Healing support needs vary by attachment wound. Patience supports anxious-type healing; independence-respect supports avoidant-type healing; consistent reassurance addresses abandonment wounds; safe vulnerability space supports trust-building. Your partner is telling you exactly how to help them heal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different healing support needs guide how to help each other. The patience-needer needs slow trust-building; the independence-respecter needs space without taking it personally.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared healing support needs make care intuitive. You know what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need from your partner to heal? Have you asked for it clearly? What would accelerate your healing?
